title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: IBGE Aggregate Data API (version 3) programmatic interface behind SIDRA, IBGE’s automatic data retrieval system. covers every survey census produced Brazilian Institute Geography Statistics. vignette explains API’s data model can make ibger. ’re familiar OLAP terminology: variables = measures, classifications = dimensions, categories = members.

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: aggregate specific table results IBGE survey. aggregate numeric ID stable time. example: 1705 — IPCA-15 — Variação mensal, acumulada ano, acumulada em 12 meses e peso mensal (Monthly change, year--date accumulation, 12-month accumulation monthly weight) 1712 — Produção, venda, valor da produção e área colhida da lavoura (Censo Agropecuário) (Production, sales, production value harvested area crops — Agricultural Census) 7060 — IPCA — Variação mensal, acumulada ano, acumulada em 12 meses e peso mensal (Monthly change, year--date accumulation, 12-month accumulation monthly weight) can filter periodicity, geographic level, subject, classification:
code: library(ibger)  # Search for aggregates ibge_aggregates() # Only quarterly aggregates ibge_aggregates(periodicity = "P10")  # Aggregates that have state-level data ibge_aggregates(level = "N3")

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: aggregate exposes one variables — measures reported. Aggregate 1712 (crop production), example, : calling ibge_variables(), can request specific variables ID: Use variable = NULL (default) standard variables, variable = "" include API-generated percentage variables available.
code: meta <- ibge_metadata(1712) meta$variables # Two specific variables ibge_variables(1712, variable = c(214, 1982), localities = "BR")

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: Besides linked locality period, observation can broken classifications (dimensions). classification contains categories (members). aggregate 1712, classifications things like “type product” (226), “producer condition” (218), “economic activity group”, etc. Classification 226 categories like “pineapple” (4844), “garlic” (96608), “potato” (96609), hundreds . don’t specify classification, API returns results Total category (ID = 0). special aggregate across categories.
code: meta <- ibge_metadata(1712) meta$classifications  # Unnest to see all categories tidyr::unnest(meta$classifications, categories) # Default: Total category (aggregated across all products) ibge_variables(1712, localities = "BR")  # Specific products ibge_variables(   1712,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = c(4844, 96608)) )  # All products (can be large) ibge_variables(   1712,   periods        = -1,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = "all") )

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: IBGE organizes Brazil hierarchy geographic levels. aggregate supports specific subset levels: Important: municipality IDs (N6) metropolitan area IDs (N7) use different numbering. São Paulo city 3550308 (N6), São Paulo metropolitan area 3501 (N7). Don’t confuse . available levels aggregate metadata: can request localities level, pick specific ones: API also supports contextual queries — filtering municipalities parent state region. example, N6[N3[33,35],N2[1]] means “municipalities RJ, SP, North region”. ibger passes directly:
code: meta <- ibge_metadata(1705) meta$territorial_level #> $administrative #> [1] "N1" "N2" "N3" # All states ibge_variables(1705, localities = "N3")  # Specific states ibge_variables(1705, localities = list(N3 = c(33, 35))) ibge_variables(   512,   variable   = 216,   periods    = -6,   localities = "N6[N3[33,35],N2[1]]" )

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: aggregate fixed periodicity: Period codes encode date periodicity. code 202001 means different things depending aggregate’s periodicity: Monthly (P5): January 2020 Quarterly (P10): Q1 2020 Semi-annual (P58): S1 2020 metadata tells valid range: ibger’s ibge_periods() lists every individual period:
code: meta <- ibge_metadata(7060) meta$periodicity #> $frequency [1] "mensal" #> $start     [1] "202001" #> $end       [1] "202512" ibge_periods(7060)

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: API allows 100,000 values per request. formula : categories × periods × localities ≤ 100,000 example, request aggregate 2654 : Classification 244: 1 category Classification 1836: 2 categories Classification 2: 2 categories Classification 260: 1 category 6 periods (default) 4 municipalities produces 1 × 2 × 2 × 1 × 6 × 4 = 96 values — well within limit. request exceeds 100,000 values, API returns HTTP 500. Reduce number localities, periods, categories retry.

title: Understanding the IBGE Aggregate Data API
text: API supports three view modes response format. ibger uses default JSON mode, can also pass view = "OLAP" view = "flat": cases, default mode ibger’s tidy output convenient.
code: # OLAP notation ibge_variables(1705, localities = "BR", view = "OLAP")  # Flat mode (first element is metadata, data starts at second) ibge_variables(1705, localities = "BR", view = "flat")

title: Getting started with ibger
text: ibger provides tidyverse-friendly interface IBGE Aggregate Data API (version 3). API powers SIDRA — automatic data retrieval system surveys censuses conducted Brazilian Institute Geography Statistics (IBGE). SIDRA table corresponds aggregate API. ibger can browse aggregates, inspect metadata, retrieve tidy data — R.

title: Getting started with ibger
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("StrategicProjects/ibger") library(ibger)

title: Getting started with ibger
text: Use ibge_aggregates() list every aggregate grouped survey. Optional filters let narrow search:
code: # All aggregates ibge_aggregates() #> ✔ 1420 aggregates found. #> # A tibble: 1,420 × 4 #>   survey_id survey_name          aggregate_id aggregate_name #>   <chr>     <chr>                <chr>        <chr> #> 1 AB        Abate de animais     1705         Animais abatidos … #> 2 AB        Abate de animais     1706         Peso total das ca… #> ...  # Monthly aggregates only ibge_aggregates(periodicity = "P5")  # Aggregates with municipality-level data ibge_aggregates(level = "N6")

title: Getting started with ibger
text: aggregate ID, ibge_metadata() tells everything structure: print method shows structured summary: component accessible directly:
code: meta <- ibge_metadata(1705) meta ── Animais abatidos ── ID: 1705 Survey: Pesquisa Trimestral do Abate de Animais Periodicity: trimestral (200101 to 202404) Territorial levels: N1, N2, N3  ── Variables (2) ──   284: Número de informantes (Unidades)   285: Cabeças abatidas (Cabeças)  ── Classifications (1) ──   12529: Tipo de rebanho bovino (9 categories)     115236: Total [level 0]     115237: Bois [level 1]     115238: Vacas [level 1]     ... meta$variables #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   id    name                  unit #>   <chr> <chr>                 <chr> #> 1 284   Número de informantes Unidades #> 2 285   Cabeças abatidas      Cabeças  meta$classifications #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   id    name                        categories #>   <chr> <chr>                       <list> #> 1 12529 Tipo de rebanho bovino      <tibble [9 × 4]>  # Unnest to see every category tidyr::unnest(meta$classifications, categories)  # Geographic levels meta$territorial_level #> $administrative #> [1] "N1" "N2" "N3"  # Time range meta$periodicity #> $frequency [1] "trimestral" #> $start     [1] "200101" #> $end       [1] "202404"

title: Getting started with ibger
text: ibge_variables() main workhorse. sends single request returns tidy tibble:
code: ibge_variables(1705, localities = "BR") #> ✔ 12 records retrieved. #> # A tibble: 12 × 9 #>   variable_id variable_name      variable_unit classification_12529 #>   <chr>       <chr>              <chr>         <chr> #> 1 284         Número de inform…  Unidades      Total #> 2 285         Cabeças abatidas   Cabeças       Total #> ... #>   locality_id locality_name locality_level period value #>   <chr>       <chr>         <chr>          <chr>  <chr> #> 1 1           Brasil        Brasil         202303 2584 #> 2 1           Brasil        Brasil         202303 7802044 #> ...

title: Getting started with ibger
text: localities parameter accepts several convenient formats: geographic level codes follow IBGE convention: Tip: every aggregate available every level. Aggregate 1705 data N1, N2, N3 N6. Use ibge_metadata() check.
code: # Country total ibge_variables(1705, localities = "BR")  # All states ibge_variables(8884, localities = "N3")  # Specific states (RJ = 33, SP = 35) ibge_variables(8884, localities = list(N3 = c(33, 35)))  # Mix levels: metropolitan areas + a specific municipality ibge_variables(1705, localities = list(N7 = c(3501, 3301), N6 = 5208707))

title: Getting started with ibger
text: Periods follow API convention — negative values mean “last N”: Note: Negative values mixed specific periods. Period codes encode date periodicity — 202001 mean January 2020 (monthly), Q1 2020 (quarterly), S1 2020 (semi-annual), depending aggregate.
code: # Last 6 periods (the default) ibge_variables(1705, periods = -6, localities = "BR")  # Last 12 periods ibge_variables(1705, periods = -12, localities = "BR")  # Specific period codes ibge_variables(8884, periods = c(202301, 202302, 202303), localities = "BR")  # Range (inclusive) ibge_variables(8884, periods = "202101-202304", localities = "BR")  # Range + extra period ibge_variables(8884, periods = "202101-202106|202301", localities = "BR")

title: Getting started with ibger
text: Many aggregates break data classifications (dimensions). instance, aggregate 1712 (crop production) classification type product (226) another producer condition (218). classification specified, API returns Total category (ID = 0) — aggregate across categories.
code: # Single category: pineapple (4844) from product classification (226) ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 1712,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = 4844) )  # Multiple categories ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 1712,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = c(4844, 96608, 96609)) )  # Multiple classifications ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 1712,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = c(4844, 96608), "218" = 4780) )  # All categories of a classification (can be large!) ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 1712,   periods        = -1,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("226" = "all") )

title: Getting started with ibger
text: sending request, ibge_variables() ibge_localities() validate parameters aggregate’s metadata. something doesn’t match, get clear error allowed values: Metadata fetched per session cached. force refresh: Skip validation entirely validate = FALSE:
code: # N3 (states) is not available for aggregate 1705 ibge_variables(1705, localities = "N3") #> Error: #> ! Geographic level(s) "N3" not available for aggregate 1705. #> ℹ Available levels: "N1", "N6", and "N7".  # Period out of range ibge_variables(1705, periods = 199901, localities = "BR") #> Error: #> ! Period(s) "199901" out of range for aggregate 1705. #> ℹ Valid range: "201202" to "202001" (monthly).  # Non-existent variable ibge_variables(1705, variable = 999, localities = "BR") #> Error: #> 355 - IPCA15 - Variação mensal (%) #> 356 - IPCA15 - Variação acumulada no ano (%) #> 1120 - IPCA15 - Variação acumulada em 12 meses (%) #> 357 - IPCA15 - Peso mensal (%) ibge_clear_cache() ibge_variables(1705, localities = "BR", validate = FALSE)

title: Getting started with ibger
text: Beyond aggregate-level data, ibger also provides access IBGE Metadata API (v2), catalogs IBGE’s surveys institutional methodological information status, category, collection frequency, thematic classifications. useful want understand surveys exist structured diving specific aggregates. Survey codes validated request. use wrong code, error suggests similar alternatives:
code: # List all 98 IBGE surveys ibge_surveys() #> # A tibble: 98 × 8 #>   id    name                                 status category    ... #>   <chr> <chr>                                <chr>  <chr> #> 1 AC    Pesquisa Anual da Indústria da Cons… Ativa  Estrutural #> 2 AA    Pesquisa Nacional de Saúde do Escol… Ativa  Especial #> ...  # Filter active monthly surveys library(dplyr) ibge_surveys(thematic_classifications = FALSE) |>   filter(status == "Ativa", category == "Conjuntural")  # Check which periods have metadata for the Censo Demográfico ibge_survey_periods("CD") #> # A tibble: 9 × 3 #>    year month order #>   <int> <int> <int> #> 1  2022    NA     0 #> 2  2010    NA     0 #> ...  # Get full institutional metadata for a specific period meta <- ibge_survey_metadata("CD", year = 2022) meta #> ── CD ── #> Status: Ativa #> Category: Estrutural #> ... #> ── Metadata occurrences (1) ── #> Use `meta$occurrences` to explore the full metadata.  # Explore methodology fields names(meta$occurrences[[1]]) ibge_survey_periods("PMS") #> Error: Survey code "PMS" not found in the IBGE catalog. #> ℹ Did you mean one of these? #>   * SC - Pesquisa Mensal de Serviços #>   * MC - Pesquisa Mensal de Comércio #>   ...

title: Getting started with ibger
text: request can return 100,000 values, computed : categories × periods × localities ≤ 100,000 exceeded, API returns HTTP 500. Split request smaller chunks working many localities categories. value column may contain special characters instead numbers: come character strings value column. Use parse_ibge_value() convert numeric one step:
code: ibge_variables(7060, localities = "BR") |>   dplyr::mutate(value = parse_ibge_value(value))

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: vignette walks realistic analysis using ibger: downloading IPCA (Índice Nacional de Preços ao Consumidor Amplo) inflation data preparing visualization reporting. IPCA Brazil’s official consumer price index, calculated monthly IBGE. data available aggregate 7060.

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: Key information metadata: Periodicity: monthly, 202001 onwards Geographic levels: N1 (Brazil), N6 (municipality), N7 (metropolitan area) Variables: monthly change (63), year--date (69), 12-month cumulative (2265), monthly weight (66) Classification 315: product groups — 365 categories organized hierarchy general index individual items
code: library(ibger) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2)  meta <- ibge_metadata(7060) meta # See what variables are available meta$variables  # Peek at the classification categories tidyr::unnest(meta$classifications, categories) |>   head(20)

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: Let’s get monthly variation last 24 months: value column character API’s special values (see ?parse_ibge_value). Use parse_ibge_value() convert:
code: ipca_br <- ibge_variables(   aggregate  = 7060,   variable   = 63,   periods    = -24,   localities = "BR" )  ipca_br ipca_br <- ipca_br |>   mutate(     value = parse_ibge_value(value),     date  = as.Date(paste0(period, "01"), format = "%Y%m%d")   )

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
code: ggplot(ipca_br, aes(date, value)) +   geom_col(fill = "#2e86c1", alpha = 0.8) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linewidth = 0.3) +   labs(     title    = "IPCA — Monthly variation (%)",     subtitle = "Brazil, last 24 months",     x = NULL, y = "Variation (%)",     caption  = "Source: IBGE via ibger"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: Get three variation variables :
code: ipca_vars <- ibge_variables(   aggregate  = 7060,   variable   = c(63, 69, 2265),   periods    = -12,   localities = "BR" )  ipca_vars <- ipca_vars |>   mutate(     value = parse_ibge_value(value),     date  = as.Date(paste0(period, "01"), format = "%Y%m%d")   )  ggplot(ipca_vars, aes(date, value, colour = variable_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) +   geom_point(size = 1.5) +   labs(     title  = "IPCA — Three measures of variation",     x = NULL, y = "%", colour = NULL,     caption = "Source: IBGE via ibger"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: Classification 315 organizes IPCA items hierarchically. top-level groups (level 1 categories) things like Food beverages (7170), Housing (7445), Transportation (7486), etc. First, find category IDs need: Now query specific groups:
code: cats <- tidyr::unnest(meta$classifications, categories)  # Level-1 groups (just below the general index) cats |> filter(category_level == "1") groups <- ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 7060,   variable       = 63,   periods        = -12,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("315" = c(7170, 7445, 7486, 7558, 7625, 7660, 7712, 7766, 7786)) )  groups <- groups |>   mutate(     value = parse_ibge_value(value),     date  = as.Date(paste0(period, "01"), format = "%Y%m%d")   )  ggplot(groups, aes(date, value, fill = classification_315)) +   geom_col(position = "dodge", alpha = 0.85) +   labs(     title = "IPCA by product group — Monthly variation",     x = NULL, y = "%", fill = NULL,     caption = "Source: IBGE via ibger"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.text = element_text(size = 7))

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: Aggregate 7060 available level N7 (metropolitan areas). Compare inflation across major cities: Pick compare:
code: # Check available metropolitan areas metros <- ibge_localities(7060, level = "N7") metros ipca_metros <- ibge_variables(   aggregate  = 7060,   variable   = 2265,   periods    = -12,   localities = list(N7 = c(3501, 3301, 2901, 4101, 1501)) )  ipca_metros <- ipca_metros |>   mutate(     value = parse_ibge_value(value),     date  = as.Date(paste0(period, "01"), format = "%Y%m%d")   )  ggplot(ipca_metros, aes(date, value, colour = locality_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) +   labs(     title   = "IPCA — 12-month cumulative by metro area",     x = NULL, y = "%", colour = NULL,     caption = "Source: IBGE via ibger"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: complete analysis, combine multiple queries. instance, download general index metro areas reshape:
code: all_metros <- ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 7060,   variable       = c(63, 69, 2265),   periods        = -12,   localities     = "N7",   classification = list("315" = 7169) )  all_metros <- all_metros |>   mutate(value = parse_ibge_value(value)) |>   select(variable_name, locality_name, period, value) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = variable_name, values_from = value)  all_metros

title: Real-world example: IPCA inflation
text: IPCA 365 categories classification 315. Querying categories periods metro areas can easily exceed 100,000-value limit. Strategies: Reduce periods: use -1 -3 instead -12 Reduce localities: query one metro time Reduce categories: pick groups need Loop bind: query chunks combine dplyr::bind_rows()
code: # Example: query all categories for just 1 period, Brazil only full_breakdown <- ibge_variables(   aggregate      = 7060,   variable       = 63,   periods        = -1,   localities     = "BR",   classification = list("315" = "all") )  nrow(full_breakdown)

text: value column returned ibge_variables() always character, IBGE API uses special codes certain data conditions. Use parse_ibge_value() convert numeric one step: function handles IBGE conventions:
code: ibge_variables(7060, localities = "BR") |>   mutate(value = parse_ibge_value(value)) parse_ibge_value(c("1.5", "10", "-", "..", "...", "X")) #> [1] 1.5  10.0  0.0   NA    NA    NA

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: vignette demonstrates query IBGE aggregate tables serve short-term tracking indicators state-level GDP components — particularly services, retail, manufacturing, construction. workflow always : Inspect metadata ibge_metadata() discover available variables, classifications, categories. Fetch data ibge_variables(), specifying aggregate, variable, classification, localities, periods. Post-process value column parse_ibge_value() convert period codes proper dates. Note value: IBGE API may return special symbols ("-", "..", "...", "X") instead numbers. Always use parse_ibge_value() convert reliably.

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
code: library(ibger) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(lubridate) library(stringr)

what: Helper: convert period codes to dates
title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: IBGE returns periods character codes: "202501" monthly data (January 2025) "202501" quarterly data (Q1 2025). need format-specific converters:
code: # Monthly periods: "202501" -> 2025-01-01 period_to_monthly <- function(x) ym(x)  # Quarterly periods: "202501" -> 2025-01-01 # lubridate::yq() expects "2025.1", so we reformat first period_to_quarterly <- function(x) {   yr <- substr(x, 1, 4)   qt <- as.integer(substr(x, 5, 6))   as.Date(paste0(yr, "-", qt * 3 - 2, "-01")) }

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: IPCA (consumer price index) aggregate 7060 main source inflation tracking. compare general index health insurance sub-item Recife Metropolitan Area.

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: Reading output: id classification ID (e.g. "315"). category_id category ID within classification (e.g. "7169" General index). ibge_variables(), pass classification = list("315" = c("7169", "7695")) request categories simultaneously.
code: meta_7060 <- ibge_metadata(7060)  # Find classification categories matching "Plano" (health plan) or "Índice" (index) unnest(meta_7060$classifications, categories) |>   filter(str_detect(category_name, "Plano|Índice")) |>   select(id, category_id, category_name, category_level)  # Available variables meta_7060$variables

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
code: ipca_health <- ibge_variables(   aggregate = 7060,   variable = 63,                          # IPCA - Monthly variation   periods = -12,   classification = list(     "315" = c("7169", "7695")             # General index + Health insurance   ),   localities = "N7[2601]"                 # Recife Metropolitan Area ) |>   mutate(     value  = parse_ibge_value(value),     period = period_to_monthly(period)   ) |>   select(period, classification_315, locality_name, value)

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
code: ipca_health |>   pivot_wider(     id_cols    = c(period, locality_name),     names_from = classification_315,     values_from = value   ) |>   arrange(desc(period))

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
code: ipca_health |>   ggplot(aes(period, value, color = classification_315)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   labs(     title = "IPCA — Health insurance vs General index",     subtitle = "Recife Metropolitan Area, monthly variation (%)",     x = NULL, y = "Monthly variation (%)", color = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: logic — category changes classification "315".
code: # Find category ID for "Seguro" (insurance) unnest(meta_7060$classifications, categories) |>   filter(str_detect(category_name, "Seguro|Índice")) |>   select(id, category_id, category_name) ipca_vehicle_ins <- ibge_variables(   aggregate = 7060,   variable = 63,   periods = -12,   classification = list("315" = c("7169", "7643")),  # General + Vehicle insurance   localities = "N7[2601]" ) |>   mutate(     value  = parse_ibge_value(value),     period = period_to_monthly(period)   ) |>   select(period, classification_315, locality_name, value) ipca_vehicle_ins |>   ggplot(aes(period, value, color = classification_315)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   labs(     title = "IPCA — Vehicle insurance vs General index",     subtitle = "Recife Metropolitan Area, monthly variation (%)",     x = NULL, y = "Monthly variation (%)", color = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: Monthly Survey Services (PMS) aggregate 8693 proxy service-sector activity. filter : Index type (classification 11046): revenue vs volume indices Activity group (classification 12355): transportation, storage postal services
code: meta_8693 <- ibge_metadata(8693)  # Browse classifications and categories unnest(meta_8693$classifications, categories) meta_8693$variables pms_transport <- ibge_variables(   aggregate = 8693,   variable = 7167,                          # Index number (2022 = 100)   periods = -12,   classification = list(     "11046" = "all",                        # All index types (revenue + volume)     "12355" = "106876"                      # Transportation/postal services   ),   localities = "N3[26]"                     # Pernambuco ) |>   mutate(     value  = parse_ibge_value(value),     period = period_to_monthly(period)   ) |>   select(period, classification_11046, locality_name, value) pms_transport |>   ggplot(aes(period, value, color = classification_11046)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   labs(     title = "PMS — Index numbers (2022 = 100)",     subtitle = "Transportation, storage and postal services (Pernambuco)",     x = NULL, y = "Index (2022 = 100)", color = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

what: 4) PNAD Contínua (5434) — Accommodation and food services
title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: Continuous PNAD aggregate 5434 provides quarterly employment data (persons aged 14+ employed) activity group.
code: meta_5434 <- ibge_metadata(5434) unnest(meta_5434$classifications, categories) meta_5434$variables pnad_accommodation <- ibge_variables(   aggregate = 5434,   variable = 4090,                          # Employed persons (thousands)   periods = -12,                            # Last 12 quarters   classification = list("888" = "56623"),   # Accommodation and food services   localities = "N3[26]"                     # Pernambuco ) |>   mutate(     value  = parse_ibge_value(value),     period = period_to_quarterly(period)   ) |>   select(period, classification_888, locality_name, value) pnad_accommodation |>   ggplot(aes(period, value)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   labs(     title = "PNAD Contínua — Employed persons (14+)",     subtitle = "Accommodation and food services (Pernambuco, thousands)",     x = NULL, y = "Employed (thousands)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Tracking state GDP components with IBGE data
text: aggregate section 3, switching activity category classification 12355:

title: ibger: Access the IBGE Aggregate Data API from R
text: sidrar closest alternative — wraps IBGE Aggregates API. key differences: Parameter ergonomics: sidrar requires single string raw API codes ("/t/1705/n3//v/284/p/last%206"), ibger uses natural R objects (ibge_variables(1705, variable = 284, localities = "N3")). Pre-flight validation: ibger checks parameters (levels, periods, variables, classifications) aggregate metadata hitting API. Invalid requests fail fast clear error messages showing allowed values, instead returning opaque API error. Metadata exploration: ibger exposes ibge_metadata(), ibge_periods(), ibge_localities() can discover aggregate offers without leaving R. Modern stack: ibger uses httr2 (automatic retry, structured error handling), cli (progress messages), returns tibbles default.

title: ibger: Access the IBGE Aggregate Data API from R
text: packages serve fundamentally different purpose. download process microdata (individual survey responses) household surveys like PNAD Contínua, POF, MUNIC, returning survey design objects suitable complex survey analysis survey package. ibger works aggregate data — pre-tabulated summary tables published SIDRA. need individual-level records proper survey weights, use PNADcIBGE SIPDIBGE. need ready-made indicators, time series, cross-tabulations (IPCA, GDP, census totals, agricultural production municipality), use ibger.

title: ibger 0.1.0
text: Initial CRAN release. Core functions: ibge_aggregates(), ibge_metadata(), ibge_periods(), ibge_localities(), ibge_variables(). Pre-flight validation aggregate metadata query parameters. -memory metadata cache ibge_clear_cache(). parse_ibge_value() utility converting IBGE special value codes. parse_sidra_url() fetch_sidra_url() migrating SIDRA API URLs (e.g. Query Builder sidrar package). Support flat view (view = "flat") response parsing. Four vignettes: getting started, API concepts, IPCA example, real-world tutorial tracking state GDP components.
